awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  The ecological significance of nitrogen fixation in perennial grasses
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide new insights into biological nitrogen fixation in perennial grasses. Nitrogen fixation is the process by which microbes convert nitrogen gas in the atmosphere to a form that can be used by the plant to make proteins, DNA, and other compounds crucial for life. This process is well-documented for legumes, i.e. plants that house nitrogen-fixing bacteria in root nodules, but it can also occur for grasses where a wide range of bacteria appear to fix nitrogen by a process known as associative nitrogen fixation. Many details of associative nitrogen fixation remain unknown, including its ecosystem importance, the microbial taxa that fix the nitrogen, and the ecological relationships driving its occurrence. Associative nitrogen fixation has potential significance for many ecosystems, and in agriculture it may help to meet the fertilizer requirements of perennial grasses grown for forage and bioenergy. If perennial grasses could get most of their nitrogen from biological fixation, it reduces the need for synthetic fertilizers, which reduces both costs to farmers and the negative environmental consequences associated with synthetic fertilizer use. The goals of this research are to determine when and how much associative nitrogen fixation occurs in perennial grasses, identify the microbial taxa fixing nitrogen, and explore the relationship between the plant and nitrogen-fixing microbes.  The project will also provide research experiences and develop teaching materials for K-12 teachers and students. 

The research will use stable isotope tracers to trace the nitrogen in switchgrass, a well-studied perennial grass native to North American prairies. They will trace labeled dinitrogen gas into switchgrass tissues and surrounding soils, as well as into the DNA of the nitrogen-fixing microbial taxa. Carbon will be traced from photosynthesis through the plant and into microbes, which will show whether the nitrogen-fixing microbes are receiving carbon from the plant or from the soil. Finally, the active nitrogen-fixing microbes will be sequenced, with the resultant genomic data providing insights into the functions of the plant microbiome.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Nitrogen (N) is a critical element for all life, because it forms the backbone of proteins and is also a component of DNA. Most N on Earth is in the atmosphere, as dinitrogen gas, a form that is unusable by most organisms. Some bacteria can ?fix? N, meaning that they can convert it to a form that plants can use. Some of these bacteria live in the soil and appear to have a loose association with perennial grasses, in which the perennial grasses can take up N fixed by the associated bacteria, allowing plants to survive in low-N environments. The importance of this process to grasses is unknown, however, in part because N fixation occurs somewhat episodically.

We hypothesized that N fixation episodes occurred post-rainfall and during times when plants have high N demand. We constructed rain-out shelters that allowed us to manipulate rainfall. We measured N fixation in intact soil cores and found that the best predictor of N fixation rates was the previous day?s rainfall and that N fixation rates decreased with N addition. After determining the conditions that influence N fixation rates, we measured N fixation under field-realistic conditions; most N fixation methods change soil conditions, potentially changing the rates from those occurring in the field.

To get field-realistic rates, we measured N fixation in mesocosms (i.e., outdoor experimental systems). The mesocosms were constructed of stainless steel. In each mesocosm, we enclosed the soil profile, with an intact switchgrass plant (see attached image showing 5 mesocosms). We placed gas-tight covers over the base and added dinitrogen gas, labeled with the rare 15N isotope, as a tracer. The 15N will show up in plants and soils only if N fixation occurs and so is a direct measurement of N fixation rates. We incubated the plants for 3 days, during which we circulated cool air, to keep the temperature and humidity within a range tolerable for the plants. The isotope was present in plant tissue and soils, which means we will be able to calculate N fixation under field-realistic conditions. In addition, we have taken samples to analyze the microbial community and trace the isotope into individual cells, so that we can determine which N-fixing bacteria were active.

In summary, we found that associative N fixation occurs episodically, with those episodes occurring after rainfall. We also will soon have field-realistic N fixation rates. Together, this knowledge will help us better understand the role of N fixation in perennial grasslands. For example, many grassland ecosystems thrive with minimal N inputs and our research will help us understand the timing and magnitude of those inputs.

Broader Impacts: This work has applications to agronomy and sustainability. Some grasses are grown commercially, for forage or for biofuels conversion. These grasses are typically fertilized with N, but N fertilizers can result in water pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. By better understanding the conditions under which N fixation occurs, growers can potentially reduce their fertilizer use, thereby reducing their costs and improving environmental conditions.

This project trained many early-career scientists. We trained six undergraduate and recent college graduates in lab and field techniques and professional development. In addition, this project funded one post-doctoral research associate, now an assistant professor, in project management, grant writing, and isotope techniques. We also worked with a high school teacher, who gained research experience and developed curriculum that uses data generated from this project. That curriculum teaches high school students to use data and it is freely available on the Data Nuggets website (datanuggets.org). By training individual students and facilitating curriculum development, this project has improved educational resources.
